Crime Simulator tries to deliver the thrill of a life of crime ‚Äî from petty thefts to larger heists ‚Äî in a sandbox world where you start broke and have to work your way up by stealing, sneaking, and upgrading your gear. It‚Äôs a familiar setup that fans of Thief Simulator will instantly recognize, but this game adds its own touches with a debt-driven story and customization options.

The gameplay loop is simple yet satisfying. You case houses, learn guard patterns, break in, and make your getaway ‚Äî all while managing risk and avoiding capture. There‚Äôs a good sense of progression as you earn money, buy better tools, and unlock new areas. The tasks are varied enough to keep things interesting, and the freedom to plan your approach gives the game a nice sense of agency.

However, Crime Simulator still feels rough around the edges. The controls can be clunky, AI behavior is sometimes inconsistent, and the environments feel small and repetitive. In its current form, it‚Äôs more of a promising prototype than a polished product. Many players have noted that it lacks the depth and fluidity of Thief Simulator 2, which it clearly draws inspiration from.

Visually, it‚Äôs serviceable but not impressive ‚Äî the lighting and models do the job but don‚Äôt stand out. The sound design adds some tension, especially during stealth segments, though it could use more variety to keep long sessions engaging.

Overall, Crime Simulator offers an entertaining experience if you‚Äôre craving a casual heist game. It has potential, and if the developers keep refining it, it could evolve into something great. But as it stands, it‚Äôs a fun but flawed crime caper ‚Äî worth trying, especially on sale or once it‚Äôs more complete.

Schedule I, Grand Theft Auto, or Payday 1 or 2 are probably going to be heavier hitters if what you're looking for is a "Crime Simulator". After playing Thief Simulator and disliking the tedium and cryptid braindead AI in that one, we're back with another project that tastes like an part-baked pie.

I'm so exhausted of "concepts" and "experiences" and "XYZ Simulators". Just because a game is possibly fun to play with friends doesn't mean it's a good game, especially if the game gets frustrating even [i]when you're playing with friends[/i].

You can read the other reviews for an in-depth examination into the quirky AI, repetitive NPC behavior, static locations and props (Save for stuff like codes, notes and mechanic-relevant items), static object physics making it easier to get stuck than to actually maneuver around, and having the Stamina of an underdeveloped child with severe asthma.

The common theme with these "Simulator"-type games is that they're pumped out almost a dime-a-dozen. You can clearly see [i]some[/i] effort has been put into this title to make it better than the previous iterations, but it's still just as patience-testing and grindy as how the original Thief Simulator felt to me.

As I usually say with these types of games; Give it a few years to develop, maybe it won't feel like such a chore to wrangle around with.

[h3]What I Liked[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Voice acting is decent, doesn't overstay its welcome. Even the AI barks - While certainly coming out of their mouths like robots - Isn't bad audio quality.
    [*] The character animations aren't as floaty or jank as previous iterations of Simulator games made by the same people.
    [*] The Skill and Ability system is interesting, with Skill books and Skill boxes. Although, the fact that it's a two-part system that both requires XP gates to gain "Skill Points" in order to make use of the Skill books reeks of artificial progression. Hopefully it'll be tweaked in the future.
    [*] Co-op support, giving the game a higher chance of staying relevant in coming years.
    [*] Varied locations offer a reason to revisit to maximize loot potential.
    [*] Expansive toolsets with various methods to approach "marks".
    [*] One doesn't require a Stethoscope to loot Safes, it just makes them easier. (Why isn't this mechanic used with other tools??) .
    [*] Jumping out of the Safehouse map fence has the Handler play a funny line before the Player gets sniped from a distance, respawning back in-bounds, which I thought was pretty funny and cleaver.
[/list]

[h3]How It's Bad[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Rudimentary NPC AI lends to both predictability in some aspects of their behavior and unpredictability in others. For example, NPCs will sometimes exit on to the street going "Who is there?" when you leave, since they're programmed to "Home in" to triggers (Like if you make too much noise, or are seen). The issue is that these triggers are extraordinarily quick to proc in the beginning due to the Player Character having.. Zero Skills.

Police response is almost immediate, offering VERY little time to compensate. Police [i]also[/i] don't run out of Stamina - [i]YOU[/i] do however - So getting away is a back-and-forth of letting my one-lunged elderly wannabe-thief regain their sweet oxygen while Police or angry Civilians keep hot on my tail.

Police Tazers are instant-kills. Regardless of if Co-op players can revive you with a Medkit, one-hit-kills regardless of Health level don't feel good, fair or balanced. Just because you can also buy a "Vest" to survive one or two doesn't make it better, it's artificial difficulty.

Police flip-flop between knowing [i]exactly[/i] where you are at all times (Likely due to overlap from the beginner Player Skill being zero, and funky behavior by the engine in regards to NPC sightlines and level geometry), or straight-up running past you.

Civilians who notice the Player will call the Police every time without fail, regardless of whether you're actively punching their lights out or smashing their face with a crowbar. There actually is no animation for Civilians calling the police (As far as I've observed), it just happens. There's zero reason to try and stop them from contacting the Police once you're seen.

Civilians follow set paths and activities depending on their AI, however the way they go about this is extraordinarily jarring. NPCs will sometimes be crouching in the middle of rooms, standing in one place occasionally turning around only to stare into nothingness, or immediately change what they're doing to begin moving to another location. There is very little telegraphing from them - If at all - Which makes circumnavigating them a frustrating chore.
    [*] Unless the Players are fulfilling Challenges, money (Credits) are impossible to gain until after one has earned enough past the "Quota", which increases with every subsequent submission. In addition, extra cash achieved through going over quota isn't distributed to the Players until the current amassed amount of stolen goods are "locked in" and submitted, leaving Players with the decision to either turn-in early to get cash to continue heisting, or enter missions without extra tools or supplies.
    [*] There's no way to heal the Player for free when at the Safehouse. You must buy and use a Medkit - Which - Are also used to revive downed Coop players.
    [*] Cameras sometimes don't show their "Red FoV" cone in certain angles, or the "edge" of the cone can become so transparent that it's difficult to see until caught. Also, Cameras catch the player [b]immediately[/b]. 
    [*] You cannot open/close doors with a "Two-handed"/"Heavy" item in your hand, requiring the Player to drop the item to interact. In a rush this easily translates to dropping the item from standing height, alerting every NPC in the house whilst also potentially blocking the door you're trying to exit from.
    [*] Figuring out how tall is "too tall" when it comes to vaulting over fences or other objects is tedious, and constantly runs the risk of over-exerting the Player whilst they try to determine if they can proceed. This is typically why other games have visual indicators for the Player in those situations.
    [*] A static physics engine in regards to level geometry makes objects as small as gnomes, standing circular grills, benches and other props impossible to move, easily creating obstacles that can freeze the Player in their tracks if one attempts to push, maneuver, or otherwise jump around them.
[/list]

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]

All in all, it's better than Thief Simulator in several aspects (Though I never played the second one), but it still falls flat heavily when it comes to NPC Intelligence, which unfortunately is a large problem right now due to the nature of the game.

Right now I'd give it a solid [b]6/10[/b]. Above average and fun with friends, but frustrating and tasking to take seriously in regards to actual forward progression.

I'm so exhausted of "concepts" and "experiences" and "XYZ Simulators". Just because a game is possibly fun to play with friends doesn't mean it's a good game, especially if the game gets frustrating even [i]when you're playing with friends[/i].

You can read the other reviews for an in-depth examination into the quirky AI, repetitive NPC behavior, static locations and props (Save for stuff like codes, notes and mechanic-relevant items), static object physics making it easier to get stuck than to actually maneuver around, and having the Stamina of an underdeveloped child with severe asthma.

The common theme with these "Simulator"-type games is that they're pumped out almost a dime-a-dozen. You can clearly see [i]some[/i] effort has been put into this title to make it better than the previous iterations, but it's still just as patience-testing and grindy as how the original Thief Simulator felt to me.

As I usually say with these types of games; Give it a few years to develop, maybe it won't feel like such a chore to wrangle around with.

[h3]What I Liked[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Voice acting is decent, doesn't overstay its welcome. Even the AI barks - While certainly coming out of their mouths like robots - Isn't bad audio quality.
    [*] The character animations aren't as floaty or jank as previous iterations of Simulator games made by the same people.
    [*] The Skill and Ability system is interesting, with Skill books and Skill boxes. Although, the fact that it's a two-part system that both requires XP gates to gain "Skill Points" in order to make use of the Skill books reeks of artificial progression. Hopefully it'll be tweaked in the future.
    [*] Co-op support, giving the game a higher chance of staying relevant in coming years.
    [*] Varied locations offer a reason to revisit to maximize loot potential.
    [*] Expansive toolsets with various methods to approach "marks".
    [*] One doesn't require a Stethoscope to loot Safes, it just makes them easier. (Why isn't this mechanic used with other tools??) .
    [*] Jumping out of the Safehouse map fence has the Handler play a funny line before the Player gets sniped from a distance, respawning back in-bounds, which I thought was pretty funny and cleaver.
[/list]

[h3]How It's Bad[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Rudimentary NPC AI lends to both predictability in some aspects of their behavior and unpredictability in others. For example, NPCs will sometimes exit on to the street going "Who is there?" when you leave, since they're programmed to "Home in" to triggers (Like if you make too much noise, or are seen). The issue is that these triggers are extraordinarily quick to proc in the beginning due to the Player Character having.. Zero Skills.

Police response is almost immediate, offering VERY little time to compensate. Police [i]also[/i] don't run out of Stamina - [i]YOU[/i] do however - So getting away is a back-and-forth of letting my one-lunged elderly wannabe-thief regain their sweet oxygen while Police or angry Civilians keep hot on my tail.

Police Tazers are instant-kills. Regardless of if Co-op players can revive you with a Medkit, one-hit-kills regardless of Health level don't feel good, fair or balanced. Just because you can also buy a "Vest" to survive one or two doesn't make it better, it's artificial difficulty.

Police flip-flop between knowing [i]exactly[/i] where you are at all times (Likely due to overlap from the beginner Player Skill being zero, and funky behavior by the engine in regards to NPC sightlines and level geometry), or straight-up running past you.

Civilians who notice the Player will call the Police every time without fail, regardless of whether you're actively punching their lights out or smashing their face with a crowbar. There actually is no animation for Civilians calling the police (As far as I've observed), it just happens. There's zero reason to try and stop them from contacting the Police once you're seen.

Civilians follow set paths and activities depending on their AI, however the way they go about this is extraordinarily jarring. NPCs will sometimes be crouching in the middle of rooms, standing in one place occasionally turning around only to stare into nothingness, or immediately change what they're doing to begin moving to another location. There is very little telegraphing from them - If at all - Which makes circumnavigating them a frustrating chore.
    [*] Unless the Players are fulfilling Challenges, money (Credits) are impossible to gain until after one has earned enough past the "Quota", which increases with every subsequent submission. In addition, extra cash achieved through going over quota isn't distributed to the Players until the current amassed amount of stolen goods are "locked in" and submitted, leaving Players with the decision to either turn-in early to get cash to continue heisting, or enter missions without extra tools or supplies.
    [*] There's no way to heal the Player for free when at the Safehouse. You must buy and use a Medkit - Which - Are also used to revive downed Coop players.
    [*] Cameras sometimes don't show their "Red FoV" cone in certain angles, or the "edge" of the cone can become so transparent that it's difficult to see until caught. Also, Cameras catch the player [b]immediately[/b]. 
    [*] You cannot open/close doors with a "Two-handed"/"Heavy" item in your hand, requiring the Player to drop the item to interact. In a rush this easily translates to dropping the item from standing height, alerting every NPC in the house whilst also potentially blocking the door you're trying to exit from.
    [*] Figuring out how tall is "too tall" when it comes to vaulting over fences or other objects is tedious, and constantly runs the risk of over-exerting the Player whilst they try to determine if they can proceed. This is typically why other games have visual indicators for the Player in those situations.
    [*] A static physics engine in regards to level geometry makes objects as small as gnomes, standing circular grills, benches and other props impossible to move, easily creating obstacles that can freeze the Player in their tracks if one attempts to push, maneuver, or otherwise jump around them.
[/list]

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]

All in all, it's better than Thief Simulator in several aspects (Though I never played the second one), but it still falls flat heavily when it comes to NPC Intelligence, which unfortunately is a large problem right now due to the nature of the game.

Right now I'd give it a solid [b]6/10[/b]. Above average and fun with friends, but frustrating and tasking to take seriously in regards to actual forward progression.

I'm so exhausted of "concepts" and "experiences" and "XYZ Simulators". Just because a game is possibly fun to play with friends doesn't mean it's a good game, especially if the game gets frustrating even [i]when you're playing with friends[/i].

You can read the other reviews for an in-depth examination into the quirky AI, repetitive NPC behavior, static locations and props (Save for stuff like codes, notes and mechanic-relevant items), static object physics making it easier to get stuck than to actually maneuver around, and having the Stamina of an underdeveloped child with severe asthma.

The common theme with these "Simulator"-type games is that they're pumped out almost a dime-a-dozen. You can clearly see [i]some[/i] effort has been put into this title to make it better than the previous iterations, but it's still just as patience-testing and grindy as how the original Thief Simulator felt to me.

As I usually say with these types of games; Give it a few years to develop, maybe it won't feel like such a chore to wrangle around with.

[h3]What I Liked[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Voice acting is decent, doesn't overstay its welcome. Even the AI barks - While certainly coming out of their mouths like robots - Isn't bad audio quality.
    [*] The character animations aren't as floaty or jank as previous iterations of Simulator games made by the same people.
    [*] The Skill and Ability system is interesting, with Skill books and Skill boxes. Although, the fact that it's a two-part system that both requires XP gates to gain "Skill Points" in order to make use of the Skill books reeks of artificial progression. Hopefully it'll be tweaked in the future.
    [*] Co-op support, giving the game a higher chance of staying relevant in coming years.
    [*] Varied locations offer a reason to revisit to maximize loot potential.
    [*] Expansive toolsets with various methods to approach "marks".
    [*] One doesn't require a Stethoscope to loot Safes, it just makes them easier. (Why isn't this mechanic used with other tools??) .
    [*] Jumping out of the Safehouse map fence has the Handler play a funny line before the Player gets sniped from a distance, respawning back in-bounds, which I thought was pretty funny and cleaver.
[/list]

[h3]How It's Bad[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Rudimentary NPC AI lends to both predictability in some aspects of their behavior and unpredictability in others. For example, NPCs will sometimes exit on to the street going "Who is there?" when you leave, since they're programmed to "Home in" to triggers (Like if you make too much noise, or are seen). The issue is that these triggers are extraordinarily quick to proc in the beginning due to the Player Character having.. Zero Skills.

Police response is almost immediate, offering VERY little time to compensate. Police [i]also[/i] don't run out of Stamina - [i]YOU[/i] do however - So getting away is a back-and-forth of letting my one-lunged elderly wannabe-thief regain their sweet oxygen while Police or angry Civilians keep hot on my tail.

Police Tazers are instant-kills. Regardless of if Co-op players can revive you with a Medkit, one-hit-kills regardless of Health level don't feel good, fair or balanced. Just because you can also buy a "Vest" to survive one or two doesn't make it better, it's artificial difficulty.

Police flip-flop between knowing [i]exactly[/i] where you are at all times (Likely due to overlap from the beginner Player Skill being zero, and funky behavior by the engine in regards to NPC sightlines and level geometry), or straight-up running past you.

Civilians who notice the Player will call the Police every time without fail, regardless of whether you're actively punching their lights out or smashing their face with a crowbar. There actually is no animation for Civilians calling the police (As far as I've observed), it just happens. There's zero reason to try and stop them from contacting the Police once you're seen.

Civilians follow set paths and activities depending on their AI, however the way they go about this is extraordinarily jarring. NPCs will sometimes be crouching in the middle of rooms, standing in one place occasionally turning around only to stare into nothingness, or immediately change what they're doing to begin moving to another location. There is very little telegraphing from them - If at all - Which makes circumnavigating them a frustrating chore.
    [*] Unless the Players are fulfilling Challenges, money (Credits) are impossible to gain until after one has earned enough past the "Quota", which increases with every subsequent submission. In addition, extra cash achieved through going over quota isn't distributed to the Players until the current amassed amount of stolen goods are "locked in" and submitted, leaving Players with the decision to either turn-in early to get cash to continue heisting, or enter missions without extra tools or supplies.
    [*] There's no way to heal the Player for free when at the Safehouse. You must buy and use a Medkit - Which - Are also used to revive downed Coop players.
    [*] Cameras sometimes don't show their "Red FoV" cone in certain angles, or the "edge" of the cone can become so transparent that it's difficult to see until caught. Also, Cameras catch the player [b]immediately[/b]. 
    [*] You cannot open/close doors with a "Two-handed"/"Heavy" item in your hand, requiring the Player to drop the item to interact. In a rush this easily translates to dropping the item from standing height, alerting every NPC in the house whilst also potentially blocking the door you're trying to exit from.
    [*] Figuring out how tall is "too tall" when it comes to vaulting over fences or other objects is tedious, and constantly runs the risk of over-exerting the Player whilst they try to determine if they can proceed. This is typically why other games have visual indicators for the Player in those situations.
    [*] A static physics engine in regards to level geometry makes objects as small as gnomes, standing circular grills, benches and other props impossible to move, easily creating obstacles that can freeze the Player in their tracks if one attempts to push, maneuver, or otherwise jump around them.
[/list]

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]

All in all, it's better than Thief Simulator in several aspects (Though I never played the second one), but it still falls flat heavily when it comes to NPC Intelligence, which unfortunately is a large problem right now due to the nature of the game.

Right now I'd give it a solid [b]6/10[/b]. Above average and fun with friends, but frustrating and tasking to take seriously in regards to actual forward progression.
